references.R89MUR01USGP: Murphy, D.D., and K.E. Freas. 1989. Recommendations for the conservation of the Amargosa River pupfish, Cyprinodon nevadensis amargosae and the Amargosa vole, Microtus californicus scirpensis. Report to The Nature Conservancy.
references.A77GIL01USGP: Gill, A. E. 1977. Food preferences of the California vole, Microtus californicus. Journal of Mammalogy, 58:229-233.
references.R98MCC01USGP: McClenaghan Jr., L.R., and S.J. Montgomery. 1998. Distribution and Abundance of the Amargosa Vole (Microtus californicus scirpensis). California Department of Fish and Game, Sacramento, CA.
references.A10NEU01USGP: Neuwald, J.L.. 2010. Population isolation exacerbates conservation genetic concerns in the endangered Amargosa vole, Microtus californicus scirpensis. Biological Conservation 143, 2028-2038.
references.R97USF02USGP: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. 1997. Amargosa Vole (Microtus caiWornicus scirpensis) Recovery Plan. Portland, Oregon. 43 pp.
references.B90ZEI02USGP: Zeiner, D. C., et al., editors. 1990. California's wildlife. Vol. II. Mammals. California Dept. Fish & Game, Sacramento. xi + 407 pp.

habitat_description:
Southwest:
In California, this species is most abundant in early seral stages of montane riparian, dense annual grassland, and wet meadow (Brylski based on Zeiner et al. 1990). It forages along the ground on grasses, sedges, and herbs adjacent to burrows (Gill 1977). Throughout its range, M. californicus occupies fresh and brackish marshes, valley annual grasslands, upland meadows as well as agricultural areas utilizing underground burrows and surface runways through vegetation (NatureServe). In Oregon, this species is associated with early seral communities with common velvet grass, blue wildrye, salal, and Oregongrape including these vegetative associations post clearcut (Borrecco and Hooven 1972, Verts and Carraway 1998).
